ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Speciation Compatibility Threshold Equation
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Welcome back, Ken. :) What were you in California for?  A conference? ... Thanks for replying so thoroughly to this question, Ken.  Though I *was* hoping

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Speciation Compatibility Threshold Equation

MIME-Version: 1.0

From: Derek James <blue5432@...>
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=34004016
X-Yahoo-Profile: blue5432

--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Hey guys, interesting discussion.  Now that I'm back
> from Cali I can
> tell you a bit about the reasoning that went into my
> handling of speciation.

Welcome back, Ken. :)

What were you in California for?  A conference?

> The truth is this is a research issue.  There should
> be experiments
> done on large genomes with N clamped to 1, and
> without.  And we could
> see the effect.  

Thanks for replying so thoroughly to this question,
Ken.  Though I *was* hoping the issue was a little
more resolved.

It does sound like another research issue.  There's no
doubt, from your ablation experiments, that speciation
is effective, but it sounds like there's no good
handle on which approaches to speciation are more or
less effective than others.

I think the basic approach Philip and I are going to
take is to calculate some sort of percentage
difference between chromosomes for usage as a
speciation threshold.  If we find that our populations
are either underspeciation or overspeciating, then
we'll modify the threshold to be dynamic.

> I included N in the forumlai in my
> papers because it
> is clearly important conceptually if not in
> practice.  But I do regret
> if it caused confusion.  

No problem.  It makes the math a lot easier. :)

Seriously, I instinctively think that normalizing for
chromosome size is conceptually important, as you
note.  That's why I was mildly surprised to realize
that it had never been used.  

Like I said, I think we're going to try to use that
approach as the default for our first experiments in
board game domains, and we'll definitely report here
about the kinds of results we're getting.

> I think in NEAT it's hard to say that as you add
> genes they are less
> significant in impact.  (Because that is the
> underlying assumption of
> normalizing with N).  Perhaps this is the case, but
> I'm not sure.  

I'm not sure either.  Intuitively, I'd be inclined to
say that adding a node to a three-node network, in
general, has a more profound effect on its behavior
than adding a node to a 500-node network.  

After all, one of the inherent features of distributed
computing approaches like neural networks is their
robustness.  A few thousand brain cells die off here
or there, a chunk of the mouse's brain is cut out, but
overall function isn't impacted significantly.  And I
would think that the robustness of the network would
only increase as the size of the network increased,
and more redundancy and distribution become features
of the system.
 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James"
> <blue5432@y...> wrote:
So the speciation mechanism for an
> indirect encoding 
> > scheme would probably need to base speciation on
> phenotype.
> 
> I strongly disagree with this.  Species in biology
> are organisms that
> share genetic history.  Those organisms in separate
> species share less
> genetic history.  And the history is *genetic* and
> not phenotypic- and
> genetic history is exactly what historical markings
> measure.  If you
> give up on that, you are left with massive analytic
> problem of
> comparing phenotypic morphologies and
> functionalities that are wildly
> complex.  But why do that when we know genetic
> history?

Hmm...I honestly hadn't thought about this much when I
answered Colin's point.  I guess I was thinking about
sex in the real world, and the fact that what
determines whether two organisms can successfully mate
is their phenotype, rather than their genotype (e.g.,
a neutered dog is genetically compatible with a
fertile one of the opposite sex, but its phenotypic,
um, limitations, keep it from mating).

That is, things that happen to phenotypes in their
environment can lead to inabilities to actually mate. 
But maybe carrying this level of literalness into the
GA domain is a bit too much.

But I don't know.  Basically, if you use an indirect
encoding scheme, the resultant organism is a
combination of genetic determinism and influences from
the environment.  If you base their compatibility
solely on their genetic similarities, aren't you
ignoring the environmental influences on the
development of an organism?  And isn't how an
indirectly-encoded phenotype develops and performs
important to determining its fitness and the extent to
which it should reproduce?

> I also disagree with the idea that changing a gene
> in indirect
> encoding can have a huge impact on phenotype.  I
> think this is only
> true in a *bad* indirect encoding.  In a good
> indirect encoding, such
> as DNA, there is canalization, which means that it's
> difficult to get
> massive perturbations in phenotype from small
> changes in genotype.  

Hmm...this is interesting.  How does this work in
nature?  I'm thinking, for example, of a millipede. 
Is it the case with the legs of a millipede that there
is a strand of DNA that encodes for a single leg, that
is then looped through to create all of the
millipede's legs?  If so, then wouldn't a mutation
that affects one leg then have a profound effect on
the organism as a whole?

I don't claim to know much about this subject.  How is
fault tolerance for indirect encoding handled by
biological organisms?  You refer to this as
"canalization", and I do remember you talking about
this in the artificial embryogeny paper, but I'm not
sure I understand the concept well.

> In
> other words, the system is more or less robust to
> change on the macro
> level.  It is important not to confuse current
> primitive indirect
> encodings with the potentially powerful indirect
> encodings we will
> ultimately use.  An encoding where flipping a bit
> can result in an
> unrecognizable phenotypic mutant is terribly
> brittle, and should not
> be the basis of our intuitions about
> complexification or speciation.

Again, I'm wondering about how biological organisms
attain this robustness.  Surely in the case of
structures (such as blood cells) that are produced
millions of times over, there is encoding for a single
blood cell.  And if a mutation occurs in that genetic
material, how is it not going to result in massive
perturbations in the phenotype?

> I do agree, it is still aquestion whether N should
> be used or not in
> any encoding, whether direct or indirect.  I believe
> I've heard that
> monkeys have 99% of the genetic history as humans. 
> Assuming this is
> true, if we were normalizing for genome size, I
> think we'd conclude
> that monkeys and people were in the same species!

Well, you probably could, with a little tweaking, get
a viable embryo that's a result of chimp and human DNA
(this may not be far off in the future).  I think this
will tend to blur the line of what a true biological
species is (which is already somewhat fuzzy).

> The issue behind the best way to use N (perhaps some
> nonlinear
> formula), if at all, is certainly an open question. 
> But I don't think
> there is any future in comparing phenotypes instead
> of genotypes.

I'm not entirely sold, but I'll admit that it is a
very interesting question. :)

> One interesting question is how a DST would interact
> with a
> normalization factor.  They may interact in
> interesting ways.
> I agree that the DST is biologically implausible. 
> But it does
> help in a practical sense, because you no longer how
> to worry about
> species explosions or implosions, and I've found it
> quite effective in
> a number of experiments.  

Yeah, Philip and I have discussed this.  It may be
that from a practical standpoint we have to stabilize
the number of species forcibly, by either clamping the
number of species, or as Joseph did, by modifying the
speciation threshold based on the amount of variation
present in the population.  I would strongly doubt
that a speciated algorithm is going to work well when
only one or two species is present in the population,
or when the number of species explodes to nearly the
size of the population.

> -No DST and no N
> -DST and no N
> -No DST and N
> -DST and N

Right.  So we're going to try door #3 first and see
what happens experimentally, though probably we'll end
up with the last option, or something like it.

Anyway, yeah...interesting discussion. :)

Derek
